title: Accepting error message on twitter sends you to attacker site

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:** Accepting error message on twitter sends you back to attacker site. **Description:** 1. The link https://twitter.com/i/flow shows up an error message with an OK button 2. When you are not logged in, clicking in that OK button takes you back to twitter.com 3. But if you open that link when you are logged in, clicking on OK takes you to the page from where you are routed to twitter. 4. This simplifies phishing attack where an attacker can take user to malicious page on clicking OK button on twitter. PS: This may not be an Open redirect using URL but a redirection that could simplify phishing attacks (CWE-601) ## Steps To Reproduce: 1. Save the following code as HTML file 2. Login to twitter and in other tab of same browser open the HTML file 3. Click on the link "Click here" 4. You are then taken to twitter and an error message is shown 5. Click OK 6. You are then reidrected to attackers site (Here in PoC I have used "https://hackerone.com/twitter") ```

This is hacker's site

Click here //This may also be made an auto-redirection to twitter from attacker site ``` ## Impact This simplifies phishing attack where an attacker can take user to malicious page on clicking OK button on twitter Possible fix might be sending the user back to twitter.com on click of OK
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary: Accepting error message on twitter sends you back to attacker site.

Description:

  1. The link https://twitter.com/i/flow shows up an error message with an OK button
  2. When you are not logged in, clicking in that OK button takes you back to twitter.com
  3. But if you open that link when you are logged in, clicking on OK takes you to the page from where you are routed to twitter.
  4. This simplifies phishing attack where an attacker can take user to malicious page on clicking OK button on twitter.

PS: This may not be an Open redirect using URL but a redirection that could simplify phishing attacks (CWE-601)

Steps To Reproduce:

  1. Save the following code as HTML file
  2. Login to twitter and in other tab of same browser open the HTML file
  3. Click on the link "Click here"
  4. You are then taken to twitter and an error message is shown
  5. Click OK
  6. You are then reidrected to attackers site (Here in PoC I have used "https://hackerone.com/twitter%22)
<html>
<body>
<h1> This is hacker's site</h1>
<a href="https://twitter.com/i/flow" onClick="userClicked()">Click here</a> //This may also be made an auto-redirection to twitter from attacker site

</body>
<script>

function userClicked(){
localStorage.setItem("ClickCount", 1);  //Setting up a value in local storage to detected user click
}


if(localStorage.getItem("ClickCount")==1)
   {
      localStorage.setItem("ClickCount", 0); 
      if(localStorage.getItem("ClickCount")==0) 
         {
            window.location.replace("https://hackerone.com/twitter");  //This can any attacker controlled website
         }
   }



</script>
</html>

Impact

This simplifies phishing attack where an attacker can take user to malicious page on clicking OK button on twitter
Possible fix might be sending the user back to twitter.com on click of OK

additional_data.old_title: Accepting error message on twitter sends you back to attacker site
additional_data.new_title: Accepting error message on twitter sends you to attacker site

activities.message:
Thank you for your report @safehacker_27,

Although this behavior is not the same as an open redirect it appears to have a very similar impact. In this case, the webpage `https://twitter.com/i/flow` will display an error which when clicked will redirect users to the last site they visited which in this case is the attacker's POC. Your POC page then detects if a user has visited their site before and redirects the victim to an arbitrary site using the `window.location.replace()` function.

At the moment, it seems this behavior can only be used in phishing attacks. Typically, we do not accept phishing attacks unless they demonstrate an extremely convincing phishing behavior. Although a victim will navigate to Twitter before being redirected to the attacker's site, we are unsure how this will help your phishing attack. Especially, since victims must navigate to the attacker's site, click a button, before being redirected to a blank Twitter error page.

Can you explain how an attacker can use this behavior to create a convincing phishing attack? 

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report @safehacker_27,

Although this behavior is not the same as an open redirect it appears to have a very similar impact. In this case, the webpage https://twitter.com/i/flow will display an error which when clicked will redirect users to the last site they visited which in this case is the attacker's POC. Your POC page then detects if a user has visited their site before and redirects the victim to an arbitrary site using the window.location.replace() function.

At the moment, it seems this behavior can only be used in phishing attacks. Typically, we do not accept phishing attacks unless they demonstrate an extremely convincing phishing behavior. Although a victim will navigate to Twitter before being redirected to the attacker's site, we are unsure how this will help your phishing attack. Especially, since victims must navigate to the attacker's site, click a button, before being redirected to a blank Twitter error page.

Can you explain how an attacker can use this behavior to create a convincing phishing attack?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

Hi @bugtriage-sophia ,

  1. Initially I thought that attacker would display something on his webpage that contains twitter's "Follow/Connect to twitter/Login With Twitter/Tweet" buttons instead of that Click here link in PoC and those buttons do all this.

  2. But as I said I could automate the click process as well, now all that attacker does is tweet a link which when opened displays an error message on twitter. Any normal user would think that it is a genuine error message from twitter and it is. And he does not expect clicking OK on twitter takes him to any other website.
    Now on the screen where error message is displayed user can only do two things. Either click OK or hit back on browser tab.
    Interestingly both actions land the user on attacker's twitter look alike page.

                 Twitter >> Attacker page (invisible) >> Twitter (error message) >> Phishing site

To achieve this use the follow code as HTML file and open it in the same browser where twitter is logged in.

<html>
<body>
<a href="https://twitter.com/i/flow" id="forceClick" onClick="forceClicked()"></a> 
</body>
<script>

function forceClicked(){
localStorage.setItem("ClickCount", 1);  //Setting up a value in local storage to detected user click
}


if(localStorage.getItem("ClickCount")==1)
   {
      localStorage.setItem("ClickCount", 0); 
      if(localStorage.getItem("ClickCount")==0) 
         {
            window.location.replace("https://hackerone.com/twitter");  //This can any attacker controlled website
         }


   }
else {

document.getElementById("forceClick").click();

}
</script>
</html>

With this, the victim does not see any attacker page or he does not have to click any link. I think clicking something on twitter then finding an error message from Twitter would convince the users strongly to click OK or go back.

It would be appropriate to send the users to twitter's home/login page on accepting error message but not the last visited webpage.

We are investigating the behavior you described and will get back to you when we have more information.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!
